job_title: Autism Support Professional in Greenville, NC
pros: Great place to gain some experience working with children and families who need extra support
cons: More of an entry level or side position job

job_title: RBT
pros: Quick start time, easy training
cons: Not enough support, easy to burn out, manager’s unprofessional, when clients called out you didn’t get paid

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Raleigh, NC
pros: The staff care SO much about the mission, in every department. I worked in the main office on the admin side of things (not directly with clients). I worked there for 3 years and it was a nice entry level job. Management was pretty good at being flexible (leaving early for a doctor's appt, not feeling well, etc.) even before COVID.
cons: The pay is very low and there wasn't much incentive to stay long-term. There was nowhere go other than a higher leadership position. You can't have a 401k with them until one year of employment and you don't get more vacation time for a long time.. I think you have to work there 5 years? It's a large organization, so there is turnover all across the state, which makes working together difficult.

review_title: I've worked in worse places but not by much
job_title: Counselor in Newport, NC
pros: Working with kido and that's it.
cons: Everything. The pay was limited. Management was unsupportive. And no room for growth.

job_title: Autism Support Staff in Greensboro, NC
pros: Being with clients is the only thing positive..
cons: The pay could be better. The benefits for hourly workers NEEDS improvement. It feels like there's hardly any good Management.

job_title: RBT
pros: Very supportive supervisors/team, flexible schedule, high quality training, great communication, great pay!
cons: Scheduling between clients can be scattered throughout the day, but not alway, it depends on the families schedule.

job_title: RBT
pros: There are a lot of resources for people or families with asd diagnosis
cons: There isn’t much support for in home techs. I didn’t feel connected to the company.

job_title: Employee in Raleigh, NC
pros:
- supportive team environment
- great opportunities for training and collaboration
- prioritizes self-advocacy, naturalistic teaching for clients
cons: I truly can't think of any. I have had experience working at multiple other companies and this is the best.

job_title: Direct Support Professional in Greensboro, NC
pros: Helping individuals in the autism community reach goals.
cons: Unorganized staff and management. No order in the day program. Not enough activities for clients. Siting most of the day doing nothing. Feels more like babysitting but less fun because there isn’t much to do.

job_title: Autism Support Assistant in Fayetteville, NC
pros: Flexible helping kids with Autism is rewarding
cons: nothing to mention at this time

job_title: Direct Support Professional in Wilmington, NC
pros: fun, independent work, never boring
cons: PAY, can easily become drained if working full-time

job_title: Autism Support Professional in Greenville, NC
pros: Building connections with clients and families, hands on learning and experiences
cons: Lack of communication with full time staff

job_title: Behavior Technician in Raleigh, NC
pros:
Families you work with
Flexible scheduling
People you work with
Supervisors are awesome
Mileage reimbursement
Above minimum wage hourly pay
cons:
Low hours (20 hours or less) (depending on client hours/schedules
Don't get paid if families cancel sessions

job_title: BCaBA/RBT in Raleigh, NC
pros: Good management, training, supervision, flexible work hours, fun work environment, fun and enjoyable clients and family
cons: No pto, no vacation, no benefits under 30 hours a week, no sick pay, no security when not working

job_title: RBT
pros: great team to work with
cons: no paid time off, no paid cancelation

job_title: Summer Camp Counselor in Moncure, NC
pros: They always check how you're doing and give you a break
cons: Helping those on the spectrum is hard work, but rewarding if it's your dream job

job_title: Camp Counselor in Winterville, NC
pros: Great environment, Room to grow
cons: It does not provide enough hours

job_title: Paraprofessional in Greenville, NC
pros: Great staff, great clients, they work with your schedule
cons: I haven't hit any downsides and it has been almost 2 years since I have started working with them.

job_title: Support Staff in Raleigh Hills, OR
pros: you get close with the people you work with and they are understanding that life happens
cons: most of the time you have to work with multiple clients to be able to get the pay you need or have to work 2 jobs

job_title: Client Services in Raleigh, NC
pros: Flexible schedule - that's about it.
cons:
The compensation and salary are below average for nonprofits. I never got a raise in 4 years, and when I finally did I was still paid undermarker and they took away my comp time so I didn't come out ahead. I wish I had left sooner but I didn't want to leave the clients hanging, I knew things would fall apart for them after I left. The parents still call me instead of their assigned client services rep they are so frustrated.

They lowered my car allowance which was already below the IRS amount. The health insurance sucks, it's basically a high deductible plan. It took a year for me to get a personal email address, I had to give clients my personal email. I never got cards with my name on it, I had to write my name on the generic cards every time I handed it out. 

They are mismanaged and things are a mess. They don't care if you work 7 days a week. I had to help clients on evenings and weekends every week and never got comp time or over time. I paid for things out of my pocket for clients and should have been reimbursed, but they could never get their act together to get me the money. 

The paperwork is overwhelming and cumbersome.

job_title: RBT
pros: Such a great place to be an employee
cons: Pay rates are low for the jobs.

review_title: I can't help you with your troubles, if you won't help with mine.
job_title: Professional Ninja Trainer in Asheville, NC
pros: ASNC has a good reputation in the community, but that has been declining quickly. Most families have terminated services due to Management turnover. Best advice : Just "pass" the participant on the goals and draw no attention from management. Ask no questions, they will tell you no lies. Participants who wanted to actually work their goals were appreciated. Supportive families who recognize quality services were always appreciated as well.
cons: Poor management. I went through 3 CEOs and 5 Qualified Professionals in less than 3 years. Most of the good hearted people have dissolved their roles at ASNC. I was hired on for $15, took a "voluntary" paycut, and the latest training class was hired at $8. Obviously, they just want "warm bodies" to babysit while the company draws over $40/hour from Medicaid. They don't care about quality and consistency of services anymore. Just "pass" the participant on the goals and draw no attention from management.

job_title: Support Staff in Asheville, NC
pros: It has a great mission and I think there are people in the company that believe in it. The families that are clients are really cool.
cons: I started working there during the pandemic, so maybe it is different under normal circumstances. There was no communication at all, I only met one person from the company and she would not text me back for days at a time. For my last two weeks, I did not have any supervisor or anyone to contact if something went wrong. I know that there were often events and zoom meetings that happened but I was never told about anything, and my appointments would randomly cancel. I did not feel welcomed by the company one bit and so it just was not worth it for me to stay with them for the little hours and little pay I got.

review_title: Great experience with kids and adults. Supervisors could care less about you
job_title: Paraprofessional in Greensboro, NC
pros: The biggest pro was working with the kids and sometimes young adults. Most families are welcoming and help you anyway they can. The experience you'll gain with this job can get you into a lot of doors if you know how to network properly.
cons: The pay is low compared to what they want you to do. The biggest con is getting a good rapport with clients and family and then your supervisor will all of a sudden switch you to another case. Most of the time, the don't even notify the family until after you've been switched. If you're part time mostly your hours are going to be unpredictable. If you need money then your schedule will need to be open from 8 AM- 9PM basically. Oh and if your client is aggressive be prepared to handle the behaviors on your own. Supervisors will barely bat an eye

job_title: Autism Support Professional in Raleigh, NC
pros: The clients are great, coworkers are wonderful people who really love what they do.
cons: If you agree to anything to help out, management will fully take advantage of that and expect you to keep doing it. Management is perfectly happy to take full advantage of their employees in this way and run them into the ground until they feel they have no choice but to leave. That's why turnover is so high, which is not fair to the employees or the clients who greatly benefit from stability. No communication whatsoever is initiated by management and you have to run around to actually get an answer from anyone about anything.

job_title: Autism Support Professional in Greenville, NC
pros: The only pro here is the clients, and sometimes you're lucky enough to have a good relationship with their families as well. It's rewarding to help them with their quality of life.
cons: When you start, they will butter you up and rant and rave about benefits, holidays, reimbursement for gas. They aren't telling the full truth at all. If you don't work on an ASNC holiday, they do not pay you. If you DO work on a holiday, you do not get any form of "holiday pay". They also do not train you before you start on how to do your time sheet or gas mileage. They throw you to the wolves and expect you do get it all done by a certain time. Sorry if you have a family to take care of after your shift(s), you have more work to do.

review_title: Terrible management, no training, and have fun documenting it all for free!
job_title: Community Skills Instructor in Raleigh, NC
pros: Interaction with great kids that deserve to be supported by a better agency.
cons: Part time csi workers are to complete all documentation within 24 hours, but they WILL NOT pay you. I was given an aggressive client with no behavior plan as a BRAND NEW employee. There is MINIMAL training, the supervisors are unorganized and do not have your best interest in mind. They don't even pay new employees for the orientation you attend! Never educated by a psychologist about a behavior plan, which they promised. Have fun driving kids all over, for little reimbursement. The parents and supervisors are never on the same page. Happiest day working for ASNC? The day I put in my two weeks.

job_title: Community Skills Instructor in Greenville, NC
pros:
great experience to prepare me for my job as an OT
supervisors are friendly and they really understand autism- I learned a LOT more than I did in classes about working with these amazing kids 
good job to have while in school, they work with your school schedule so you can keep working while going to school 
Everyone really cares about the kids and adults learning, it is not just a babysitting job so I liked that it was meaningful work
Supervisors are really approachable and have an open door policy
cons:
mileage reimbursement is low and you have to transport
some services pay at a lower rate, but less paperwork for those

job_title: Autism Support Professional in Raleigh, NC
pros: Learned about how to work with individuals who have Autism, great benefits.
cons: Raises are very rare even with almost perfect performance reviews, and bonuses are small and only given when reaching a certain number of years of employment. Have to complete clinical notes off the clock at home. Day program is great but someones a 1:1 staff ends up caring for 3 clients. It's difficult to get people to cover your shift in the community.

review_title: You get some great interaction with kids, but the supervisors seem disorganized and distracted. Training is minimal.
job_title: Community Skills Instructor in Asheville, NC
pros: The interaction with kids is amazing. They are awesome and it is fun hanging out with them and learning from them.
cons: Supervisors are very disorganized. Communication between workers and families seems nonexistent and often leaves the personal staff in the dark. Pay is small. Hard to get needed work hours as most of the kids are only available after school.

job_title: Community Skills Instructor in Greenville, NC
pros: The children are my only motivation to work here. The children are amazing and you get to learn from them while helping them learn from you.
cons: Pay is terrible, especially for high risk clients. Management is always changing and very disconnected. Paperwork is extremely demanding and so many unpaid hours go into the paperwork, transportation, and planning for clients.

job_title: Community Skills Instructor in Raleigh, NC
pros: Compensation for gas, flexible hours, diverse environment, hands-on experience, never doing the same thing every day, kind supervisors, it's fun!
cons: Poor benefits, low full time salary, difficult to work your way up in the company, unorganized leadership, miscommunication between families and workers.

review_title: dont' choose ASNC to provide autism services
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Asheville, NC
pros: great kids to work with
cons: No training required; poor communication with families; pay workers little and keep the rest of the money from Medicaid; unethical

job_title: Autism Support Professional in Fayetteville, NC
pros: ASNC is a great place to work. You don't have to worry about your supervisors looking over your shoulders all the time because they entrust that you will do your job. Also the pay is great once you get in.
cons: If you dont have  a vehicle its going to be hard to work at ASNC.

job_title: General Instructor in Raleigh, NC
pros: I had flexible hours, solid hourly wage for a graduate student, and great management and coworkers.
cons: The work could be a little boring at time. Coworkers seemed like they may be unqualified for the work. High staff turnover.

job_title: in Raleigh, NC
pros: Great immediate and secondary supervisors, flexible hours.  Most of the staff really believed in the mission and worked together for a common goal.
cons: Mishandling of funds, major overhaul of upper management

job_title: "Community Skills Instructor"/"CAP Worker"/"habilitation Technician" in Greenville, NC
pros: Create your own routine, lots of interaction with clients and staff, very rewarding work
cons: Staff was disorganized on several occasions with trainings as well as assigning clients to employees, clients' guardians may remove them from ASNC services at any time which can leave you without an income until the supervisor can assign you another client.

job_title: Community Skills Instructor in Fayetteville, NC
pros: Clients are great.  Loved working with the families
cons: To be experts in autism, ASNC does not provide the CSI with enough on the job training.  Staff is not giving enough support to work with clients.  Consistent training is needed to work with clients but in most often never provided.  No opportunities to grow within the organization unless you meet the status que look at the website at leadership and clinical experts).  Not a Representive of the population we work with.

review_title: Multitasking skills are require as well as supervision and hiring staff
job_title: Community Service Coordinator in Asheville, NC
pros: Flexibility and opportunities to grow and promotion
cons:
high volume of responsibility
high demands are expected from families
after staff are hired and train they will leave the company due to the challenges of working with individuals affected by DD/MH

review_title: Great part-time job for current psych majors or recent graduates.
job_title: Community Skills Instructor in Raleigh, NC
pros:
Clients and staff were really fun to work with, in my experience.
Clear outline of expectations and procedures.
Practical experience in understanding Autism.
cons:
Little to no room for growth.
Pay was just alright.

review_title: Great company for a part time position
job_title: Registered Behavior Technician in Raleigh, NC
pros: Great training and supportive supervisors! Very fun job and a lot of learning opportunities. They also pay for you to become certified and you get a dollar pay raise.
cons: Clients cancel often, and the hours are unstable. There is no paid time off.

review_title: Better pay than other agencies for direct care, but less guidance
job_title: Community Skill Instructor in Greenville, NC
pros:
Higher pay than other agencies
Mileage compensation
Flexibility with schedule
Office resources such as sensory rooms
cons:
No guidance for those new to direct care
Do not recognize hard working staff
Take staff for granted
Supervisors lack support for staff

review_title: Stick with ASNC. It will get better
job_title: Billing & Human Resources Coordinator in Raleigh, NC
pros: Somewhat flexible schedule. Decent pay. Low but fair mileage reimbursement. Wonderful people. Friendly leaders. Joyful environment.
cons: Unrealistic expectations of staff. Their HR Dept is always overworked as are most employees. Benefits not that great.

job_title: Instructor in Raleigh, NC
pros: Great coworkers that give lots of support and help.
cons: Management is very backstabbing. Will smile to your face while trying to get rid of different employees. Looking for ways to cut your pay, or not pay you at all. Certain managers will not help employees at all and very condescending.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Greenville, NC
pros: Great family to work with in Greenville.  Set schedule which makes it great for work/school balance.  Everyone is very nice and welcoming
cons: Not much bad to say.  Better communication between skills instructors and office.

job_title: Habilitation Technician in Asheville, NC
pros: Excellent management staff and a functional organization
cons: Choice of clients and shifts is not very high, nor are real career opportunities readily available.

review_title: An amazing, pro-autism place to work!
job_title: Direct Support Professional in Greensboro, NC
pros: Very progressive and inclusive philosophy, especially compared to other organizations. The managing staff are amazing, personal, and passionate. Really easy to get lots of hours.
cons: Pay and sometimes hires underqualified staff

job_title: Direct Associate in Raleigh, NC
pros: Will work with your schedule. In addition, Autism Society will make sure you are comfortable in the work that you do.
cons: If I were to pick a downside it would be the low pay rate.

job_title: in Reston, VA
pros: Work on goals with individuals, this could vary based on the individual. Got to experience a different way of seeing the world.
cons: Not many other than sometimes scheduling could get thrown off.

job_title: Autism Support Professional in Greenville, NC
pros: Flexible Schedules, great people to work with, clients were great.
cons: A lot of unqualified people were hired.

job_title: Camp Counselor in Wilmington, NC

review_title: Fine if you're in high school...
